title: 106_hr1942
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so we will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that free trade agreements benefit citizens by improving income and prosperity through open markets. APEC member economies aim for "free and open trade" by 2020 for developing countries and 2010 for developed countries. Leaders of APEC member economies committed to achieving "free and open trade" by 2020 for developing countries and 2010 for developed countries. This is crucial for economic growth, creating new trade opportunities, and reducing trade barriers, which is in the strategic interest of the United States in the Pacific Rim region. The financial crisis in Asia has also had an impact. The financial crisis in Asia has disrupted United States export growth in the Pacific Rim region, amidst increasing pressures for protectionist policies. Free trade agreement negotiations are crucial for the strategic and economic interests of the United States in the region. During the years 1989-1997, free trade agreement negotiations were important for the United States amidst global economic challenges. Countries like New Zealand, Australia, and Singapore were allies in promoting trade liberalization for economic growth. Coordination with these countries was crucial for market opening measures. Australia, Singapore, and the United States are long-time allies working together to increase economic growth through trade liberalization in organizations like the World Trade Organization and APEC. Building closer ties with friendly countries will be beneficial as trade negotiations for liberalization progress in the next century. The United States must continue to promote its interests in the Asia-Pacific region through aggressive trade and investment strategies. In the next century, trade liberalization must proceed, with the United States promoting its interests in the Asia-Pacific region through aggressive trade and investment negotiations. Bilateral trade talks can positively influence multilateral and regional trade negotiations by expanding common areas of agreement on trade disciplines. Trade negotiations aim to enlarge common areas of agreement on trade disciplines, facilitating successful advancement in larger negotiations with additional trading partners. Resolving trade and investment disputes between the United States and Pacific Rim countries can be more effective through mutually agreed-upon disciplines and dispute settlement mechanisms, rather than issue-by-issue confrontations under trade remedy laws. This provides a solid foundation for enhanced trade relations. Free trade agreements between the United States and Pacific Rim countries aim to enhance cooperation and ensure mutually beneficial economic and political relations by providing market access and understanding for US firms in Pacific Rim markets. Free trade agreements aim to stabilize the bilateral trade balance between the United States and Pacific Rim countries by enhancing market access for US firms in the region. The United States aims to enhance trade policy with eligible Pacific Rim countries. The United States aims to eliminate tariff and nontariff barriers through bilateral free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries, addressing issues such as regulatory barriers, foreign investment treatment, and intellectual property protection. The United States aims to address issues such as denial of national treatment to foreign direct investment, lack of protection for intellectual property, arbitrary standards, government measures restricting market access, and unfair trade activities in bilateral free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries. The United States aims to address issues such as denial of national treatment to foreign direct investment, lack of protection for intellectual property, arbitrary standards, government measures restricting market access, and unfair trade activities in bilateral free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries, including pricing and unreasonable restrictions on listings for government-established formularies which deny full market access for United States products, and unfair or trade-distorting activities of State trading enterprises and other administrative mechanisms. SEC. 3. PRENEGOTIATION CONSULTATIONS. Within 60 days of enacting the Act, the President will identify and consult with eligible Pacific Rim countries. If consultations show potential for a free trade area, a ministerial meeting will be requested within 60 days to discuss formal negotiations for a free trade agreement. The President will request a ministerial meeting with eligible Pacific Rim countries within 60 days after consultations to discuss formal negotiations for a free trade agreement. The United States International Trade Commission will advise the President on the economic effects of providing duty-free treatment for products of that country on US industries. The United States International Trade Commission will advise the President on the economic effects of providing duty-free treatment for products of eligible Pacific Rim countries on US industries and consumers. SEC. 4. MINISTERIAL MEETING RECOMMENDATIONS. The President recommends establishing a council of public and private sector officials to review aspects of the bilateral relationship for a free trade agreement negotiation. This includes analyzing trade practices, customs laws, and economic data harmonization. The President recommends establishing a council to review aspects of the bilateral relationship for a free trade agreement negotiation, including trade and investment practices, customs laws, economic data harmonization, and bilateral disputes. Within 6 months, a report on the overall bilateral relationship and prospects for a successful negotiation will be issued. Within 6 months of establishment, a report will be issued on the overall bilateral relationship and prospects for a successful negotiation of a free trade agreement, examining possible benefits, adverse effects, and appropriate dispute settlement mechanisms. Within 6 months of establishment, a report will be issued on the feasibility and desirability of negotiating free trade agreements with eligible countries. The President will determine the feasibility of negotiating a free trade agreement with eligible Pacific Rim countries within 6 months of receiving a report from a bilateral council. The President will determine the feasibility of negotiating a free trade agreement with eligible Pacific Rim countries and submit a report to the Senate and House committees. Factors considered include membership in the World Trade Organization. When considering the feasibility and desirability of establishing a free trade area between the United States and an eligible country, the President will assess if the country is a member of the World Trade Organization, has shown interest in negotiating a bilateral free trade agreement with the US, has implemented trade liberalization and economic reforms, and has a strong affinity for the United States. The country has an open economy, aligns with US trade policy objectives, and actively participates in World Trade Organization negotiations. The country, from November 30 to December 3, 1999, has shown commitment to US objectives in WTO negotiations, working to eliminate export requirements, harmonize standards, and increase economic opportunities for small- and medium-sized businesses through deregulation. The country is committed to US objectives in WTO negotiations, focusing on transparency, nondiscrimination, deregulation for small- and medium-sized businesses, eliminating trade barriers, providing national treatment for foreign investment, accommodating US market access objectives, and resolving trade disputes constructively. The country is committed to US objectives in WTO negotiations, focusing on transparency, nondiscrimination, deregulation for small- and medium-sized businesses, providing national treatment for foreign investment, and resolving trade disputes constructively. Additionally, the country's market for US products and services will benefit from improved dispute settlement mechanisms and enhanced trade by eliminating tariff and nontariff barriers. The President must consult regularly with the House Committee on Ways and Means and the Senate Committee on Finance regarding the implementation of the Act. The Act defines "APEC" as the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum and "eligible Pacific Rim country" as a WTO member and a member economy of APEC.
